intro: Valeriana ramosa, commonly known as the branched valerian, is a flowering plant native to regions of Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring upright stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are usually pink or white, blooming in late summer. Valeriana ramosa is known for its aromatic foliage, which contains essential oils and has been used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and woodland edges.
